title: FIFA probe: Quotes from Sepp Blatter’s career
text:
Print Article 
FIFA president Sepp Blatter speaks at the 65th FIFA Congress in Zurich, May 29, 2015. — Reuters pic 
ZURICH, Oct 9 — Sepp Blatter, who was suspended from football for 90 days yesterday as a mounting corruption scandal engulfed world football’s governing body FIFA, is famed for his controversial quotes. 
Here are ten that have marked football history: 
“It seems to me that I am being held to blame for all the ills of the world: the destruction of the rainforests, the rail strike in Germany, frequent volcanic eruptions in Iceland, and — it goes without saying — fluctuations on the world’s stock markets.” 
Blatter in an address to Zurich’s Academic Sports Association subsequently published in FIFA magazine in November last year. 

“I am convinced that evil will come into the light and good will triumph.” 
Blatter to German magazine Bunte in an interview published hours before FIFA’s ethics watchdog handed him and UEFA head Michel Platini 90-day suspensions. 

“Crisis? What is a crisis? Football is not in a crisis.” 
Blatter in May 2011 amid an earlier major corruption scandal. 

“I would deny it. There is no racism ... We are in a game, and at the end of the game, we shake hands, and this can happen, because we have worked so hard against racism and discrimination.” 
Blatter sparks controversy in November 2011 when asked in a television interview if he believes there is racism in the game. 

“I’d say they should refrain from any sexual activities.” 
Blatter in December 2010 when asked about the 2022 World Cup being held in Qatar, where homosexuality is illegal. 

“Let the women play in more feminine clothes like they do in volleyball. They could, for example, have tighter shorts. Female players are pretty, if you excuse me for saying so, and they already have some different rules to men—such as playing with a lighter ball. That decision was taken to create a more female aesthetic, so why not do it in fashion?” 
Blatter in 2004 talking about women’s football. 

“I consider myself a little bit as a godfather of the organisation of women’s football in FIFA.” 
Blatter in 2015, urging better marketing of women’s football ahead of the World Cup in Canada. 

“Listen, this is a special approach in the Anglo-Saxon countries. If this had happened in, let’s say, Latin countries then I think he would have been applauded.” 
Blatter says in 2010 John Terry ought not to have been sacked as England captain over an alleged affair. 

“Every game should have a winner. When you play cards or any other game, there’s always a winner and a loser. We should have the courage to introduce a final decision in every game of football.” 
Blatter in 2004 when proposing the possibility of abolishing draws and making goals bigger. 

“There are not many names the media haven’t thrown at me in the last few years. I would be lying to you if I said it did not hurt. You ask yourself: ‘What have I done?’” 
Blatter in 2014 discussing his treatment by the international media. — AFP
